cross-stich, the moderator for this forum (Bev, aka Barkyboys) is away for a couple of days but will be back soon and she will respond to your post.  I wish I could help you but I don't know anything about
 this.  Sorry.
Posts.Title: 6mm breast nodule

Posts.Content:
Hi Nans4, I also had an abnormal mammo some years ago when I was in my 50's. They said it looked like fibrous tissue. This was before the newer mammos which are now digital so they did a needle biopsy. It was fibrous tissue and I was told not to drink a lot of caffeine. (I don't! And I never did anyway.) But today they have much better equipment to read what's going on in there. If you can ask for a digital screening, maybe that would be helpful. Look at this link: 
Good luck!
Posts.Title: Abnormal mammogram

Posts.Content:
Welcome to HealingWell, C Hall. I am not a moderator in this forum but I wanted you to know that when someone responds you will be able to read the post just as you're reading mine. There is also an "edit" feature on the right side just above posts and if you need to change, correct or add to your post, you can just click on the pencil and you can do whatever you need to your original post and then click "submit".
I have not had breast cancer but a few years ago I had a mammogram and was also called back for more views because of denseness and fibroids. After they did a small biopsy to rule out any cancer, they just told me not to drink a lot of caffeinated beverages and that was that. I hope it all goes well for you, too. I know you're concerned but I'm glad you're in touch with your doctor's office now. Good luck!
Posts.Title: call back after mammo

Posts.Content:
Hi again. You can click "Reply" at the bottom of the post and then you can write your response and then click "Submit". This way, all responses will be within the same thread, not as separate posts.
Congratulations on your clean bill of health after the surgery last year! I hope this continues! And for the mammo callback, I'm glad they are being cautious and thorough even though I know it's nerve-wracking.
Posts.Title: call back after mammo

Posts.Content:
C Hall wrote: Thank you Lainie! I will learn to navigate through the site eventually...your information was very helpful! I appreciate your encouragement as well...one thing I want to add is that last year in May I was diagnosed with colorectal cancer...have had treatment...surgery and now have a permanent colostomy but am doing great! When the surgeon went in she could see nothing remaining of the tumor...only scar tissue. I didn't have to have any more treatment and they say I'm cancer free. I tell you this because it hasn't even been a year since that diagnosis and I'm pretty nervous about
 this call back for that reason specifically. Again...they were reassuring and stressed that the paperwork said they didn't see anything. She also said that sometimes it's not what they see but what they CAN'T see..that they sometimes just need more views. Thank you again for the help...I really appreciate it!
Posts.Title: call back after mammo
Why am I NOT high risk?

Posts.Content:
I think you need to see your doctor.  Only a doctor can determine what this is.  The doctor would probably do a physical exam and you might have a mammogram.  I know you and your mom are probably worried about
 this, so the sooner you see a doctor, the better you'll both feel.  I wish you good luck!
Posts.Title: 17 and scared

Posts.Content: Smurf, I didn't know you had breast cancer?
Posts.Title: Why is remission short lived?

Posts.Content:
In my opinion (which is as a woman, not a doctor because I'm not one!), you are making the right decision to have it biopsied. When I was in my 40's, a mammogram showed I had fibroid tissue in one breast and the radiologist suggested having it biopsied. There is no breast cancer in my family but even so, I felt there should be no other choice but to have it biopsied. With your family history, I cannot understand why a doctor would say you're not a 'high risk'. What on earth is their reasoning?
I wish you the best of luck with this and hope the biopsy is negative. At the same time, I would not return to the doctor(s) who told me I wasn't a high risk!
Posts.Title: Why am I NOT high risk?

Posts.Content:
Exactly. Sure, they may have a formula based on a certain number of active cancer patients but that doesn't mean the next patient will test positive or negative in my opinion. Their 'formula' is not 100%. If I were a doctor, I would want to err on the side of caution. Only then could you rest easy. 
When I went through the fibroid experience, I was told not to drink a lot of caffeine as that seems to make fibroids worse or more common. Well, I drink one cup of coffee (sometimes two) a day and that's it, no cokes. Also, I had read that it's best not to take HRT which is what I was taking at the time and I stopped.
So, the bottom line is you have to be pro-active on your health. Be informed and ask questions. Maybe other women will come here and respond with their particular experience which is closer to yours. In the meantime, from what you wrote, I think you're making the best decision. Best of luck with that. Please come back and post how everything went. I'm not a moderator on this forum and I haven't had breast cancer but I would like to read your follow-up!
Posts.Title: Why am I NOT high risk?

Posts.Content: Yes, Bev, you've been through some battles.  Congratulations and best wishes to you and all women who have faced this disease!

Posts.Title: Sorry I've been out of touch...

Posts.Content: You can delete all your old posts by signing in with your old name again.  You will see a list of your posts when you go to your "profile" page.  Then, you can click on each post you see listed there which will take you directly to that page and you can delete your post by clicking the X in the top right corner of your post.  Do that for all the posts that you see listed on your profile page.  In this way, no posts under that name will exist.
